questions.prompt: A function f: A → B is:
options: Any relation between A and B
A relation where each element of A is related to exactly one element of B
A relation where each element of B is related to at least one element of A
A bijection between A and B
questions.explanation: A function assigns to EACH element in the domain A EXACTLY ONE element in the codomain B. Not all relations are functions.

questions.prompt: A function f: A → B is injective (one-to-one) if different inputs always produce different outputs.
questions.explanation: Injective means if f(a₁) = f(a₂), then a₁ = a₂. Equivalently, if a₁ ≠ a₂, then f(a₁) ≠ f(a₂).

questions.prompt: A function f: A → B is surjective (onto) if:
options: Every element of A maps to a unique element of B
Every element of B is the image of at least one element of A
questions.explanation: Surjective means the range equals the codomain. Every element of B is "hit" by some element of A.

questions.prompt: A function f: ℝ → ℝ defined by f(x) = x² is:
questions.explanation: f(x) = x² is not injective because f(-2) = f(2) = 4. It's not surjective because negative numbers are not in the range. So it's neither.

questions.prompt: A function that is both injective and surjective is called a ____.
questions.explanation: A bijection (bijective function) is one-to-one (injective) and onto (surjective). Bijections have inverses.

questions.prompt: Every bijective function has an inverse function.
questions.explanation: True. A function must be bijective (both injective and surjective) to have an inverse. The inverse reverses the mapping of the original function.

questions.prompt: If f(x) = 2x + 1 and g(x) = x², what is (g ∘ f)(3)?
For f: A → B and g: B → C, what is the domain and codomain of g ∘ f?
questions.explanation: The composition g ∘ f goes from A to C. We apply f first (A → B), then g (B → C), so overall: A → C.

questions.prompt: If f: A → B is injective and |A| = |B| where both are finite, then f is also surjective.
questions.explanation: For finite sets of equal size, an injection must be a surjection. Since no two elements of A map to the same element of B (injection), and |A| = |B|, every element of B must be hit.

questions.prompt: The floor function ⌊x⌋ gives the greatest integer less than or equal to x. What is ⌊-2.7⌋?
questions.explanation: ⌊-2.7⌋ = -3 because -3 is the greatest integer that is ≤ -2.7. Note: -2 > -2.7, so -2 doesn't qualify.

questions.prompt: If f: A → B has an inverse f⁻¹, what is f⁻¹(f(a)) for any a ∈ A?
questions.explanation: By definition of inverse: f⁻¹(f(a)) = a for all a in A, and f(f⁻¹(b)) = b for all b in B.

questions.prompt: The composition of two injective functions is always injective.
questions.explanation: If f and g are injective, then (g ∘ f)(a₁) = (g ∘ f)(a₂) implies g(f(a₁)) = g(f(a₂)), which implies f(a₁) = f(a₂) (g injective), which implies a₁ = a₂ (f injective).

questions.prompt: If |A| = 5 and |B| = 3, how many surjective functions exist from A to B?
questions.explanation: Using inclusion-exclusion: 3⁵ - C(3,1)·2⁵ + C(3,2)·1⁵ = 243 - 96 + 3 = 150 surjective functions. (This counts onto functions from 5 elements to 3.)

questions.prompt: If f: ℤ → ℤ is defined by f(n) = n + 5, which properties does f have?
questions.explanation: f(n) = n + 5 is injective (different n give different n+5) and surjective (every integer m equals n+5 for n = m-5). So f is bijective.

questions.prompt: The number of bijections from a set with n elements to itself equals n! (n ____)
questions.explanation: There are n! = n × (n-1) × ... × 2 × 1 bijections (permutations) from a set of n elements to itself.
